description:
Amphipyra tragopoginis, commonly known as the Mouse Moth, is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae. It is a medium-sized moth with a wingspan of around 35-45 millimeters.

The Mouse Moth has distinctive coloration, with greyish-brown forewings and hindwings that are pale grey or whitish. The forewings often have a darker central area and a lighter outer area, giving the appearance of a "mouse-like" pattern. The hindwings have a faint discal spot and a dark terminal line.

The larvae of the Mouse Moth are typically greyish-brown or greenish-brown in color, with a distinctive dark head capsule. They feed on a variety of herbaceous plants, including dandelions, chicory, and other members of the Asteraceae family.

The Mouse Moth is widely distributed across Europe and parts of Asia, and can be found in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, meadows, and gardens. It is considered a common and widespread species within its range.
